case_vignette: A 20-year-old male college student presents to the emergency room with persistent vague abdominal pain, vomiting, and nausea. Notably, he also reports getting full with meals sooner than usual. He has recently been pledging at a fraternity and has participated in binge drinking, marijuana use, cocaine use, and intramural sports. He admits to sharing drinks and paraphernalia with other fraternity members and states that several of them have been ill recently. The patient has a past medical history of asthma and depression. He admits to using large amounts of ibuprofen recently to control pain secondary to minor orthopedic injuries from intramural sports. Physical exam demonstrates mild tachycardia and epigastric tenderness. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. A CT scan is performed and shown in Figure A.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have persistent vague abdominal pain, vomiting, and nausea, and I get full quicker than usual when eating meals.
Have you had any changes in your weight or appetite recently?
Yes, I get full with meals sooner than usual.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or eating habits?
I've been getting full quicker than usual, but I didn't change my diet.
Have you had any recent changes in your stress or sleep patterns?
I didn't mention any changes in my sleep or stress levels.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to new environments?
I've been spending time at my college fraternity and shared drinks and stuff with others who've been sick.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication or supplements?
I have been using a lot of ibuprofen lately for pain from sports injuries.
Have you had any recent changes in your medical history or family history?
I have a history of asthma and depression, but I haven't mentioned any recent changes or family history.
Final Diagnosis: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
